meaning_mnemonic: The sun is coming up out of the ground, making this radical <radical>dawn</radical>. Of course, don't confuse this with dusk! You can do that by thinking that the sun is an optimistic and bright thing, so it tends to come up, not go down. (Also, Japan is the Land of the Rising Sun. I mean come on!)

There are five mouths eating cow at <radical>Korea</radical>n BBQ. Korea is famous for their delicious BBQ, and you need a lot of people to eat all that beef. At least five people. (Get it? Five people!) That's why this radical is Korea.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>guest</radical>.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>control</radical>.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>nature</radical>.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>accept</radical>.

There is a hat covering the moon and it's holding a knife. Wait, that's no moon. It's a space station! It's the <radical>Death Star</radical>! It's pretending to be a moon under that hat. And it's armed! Don't let the Death Star stab your planet to death.

You're about to enter a <radical>roof</radical> that has your <radical>number</radical> on it so you can face the <kanji>judge</kanji>. You've been sitting here for what feels like hours, waiting for your number to come up. Finally the time has come—the judge will see you now.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>judge</kanji> is not happy with you. He tells you to come closer and when you do, he takes his gavel and hits you in the <reading>shin</reading>s (しん). Ouch!

meaning_mnemonic: A man who is <radical>husband</radical> material can <radical>see</radical> a <kanji>standard</kanji> woman and think she’s the greatest thing ever. This man will make a great husband. Even though the lady is pretty standard, the husband treats her like she’s anything but.
reading_mnemonic: It’s pretty <kanji>standard</kanji> for a husband and wife to exchange vows when getting married, and the husband said this girl held the <reading>key</reading> (き) to his heart. She unlocked the husband’s heart with the key and now he’s a man made whole.

meaning_mnemonic: You use your <radical>fingers</radical> at <radical>dawn</radical> to <kanji>carry</kanji> many things. You have to carry yourself out of bed. You have to carry your backpack or purse or laptop bag to school or work. Your fingers have to carry a lot of weight around at dawn.
reading_mnemonic: Once you're <kanji>carry</kanji>ing everything, and the dawn sun is shining bright, you start getting <reading>tan</reading> (たん). Especially those fingers you're using to carry things.

meaning_mnemonic: When you're a <radical>guest</radical> somewhere it's important to bring <radical>geoduck</radical>s. But more than that, the <kanji>amount</kanji> of geoducks you bring is really what matters. If you don't have any live geoducks go ahead and bring any amount of <kanji>framed picture</kanji>s of geoducks instead.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, if you mess up the <kanji>amount</kanji> or the <kanji>framed picture</kanji>s, every other guest will <reading>gawk</reading> (がく) at you.

meaning_mnemonic: In an attempt to <radical>control</radical> your <radical>clothes</radical>, you <kanji>manufacture</kanji> a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>manufacture</kanji> these clothes to control your <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). It's hard to manufacture, you have to do a lot of work, but you manage to make your clothes control your saber. Now you don't need to rely on your hands!

meaning_mnemonic: You take your <radical>scooter</radical> to <radical>Korea</radical> and everything is <kanji>different</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: What's also <kanji>different</kanji> is that there's a weird tiger bouncing on its tail alongside you yelling that its name is <reading>Tigger</reading> (ちが). You didn't know Tigger was living in Korea these days. That's definitely different.

meaning_mnemonic: What does a <radical>car</radical> and the <radical>Death Star</radical> have in common? They're both used to <kanji>transport</kanji> people and things.
reading_mnemonic: Right now you and the Death Star are <kanji>transport</kanji>ing <reading>yu</reading>rts (ゆ). They're the universe's #1 best transportable homes!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Fire</radical> in <radical>nature</radical> will <kanji>burn</kanji> down everything in its path. In nature, there are no firefighters to contain the flames, so the <kanji>blaze</kanji> will burn until nothing's left.
reading_mnemonic: What is the worst thing that could <kanji>burn</kanji> in this fire? Your <reading>nen</reading>doroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>spirit</radical> blesses your <radical>older brother</radical> it's time to <kanji>celebrate</kanji>! This isn't something that happens every day to everyone's older brother. Yours is very good and very lucky. So celebrate with him!
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, the two of you <kanji>celebrate</kanji>d too much, and you went a little crazy. The spirit grabbed your brother and <reading>shook</reading> (しゅく) him. Shook him so hard his head popped off.

meaning_mnemonic: The American <radical>flag</radical> is the <radical>reason</radical> you need to <kanji>deliver</kanji> this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need?
reading_mnemonic: To <kanji>deliver</kanji> this flag is something you just have <reading>to do</reading> (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do.

meaning_mnemonic: You have an <radical>animal</radical> for a <radical>husband</radical> with <radical>horns</radical> that are <kanji>narrow</kanji>. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why.
reading_mnemonic: I’m not even going to get into the <reading>sema</reading>ntics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and <kanji>narrow</kanji>. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>door</radical> leading to the <radical>moon</radical> can be broken down with one’s <kanji>shoulder</kanji>. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram it open.
reading_mnemonic: "Wow, your <kanji>shoulder</kanji> is just like my <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた)!" you hear someone shout. As you turn you're just in time to see a man catapulting through his own moon door!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>moon</radical> shines on your <radical>roof</radical> in the <radical>evening</radical> and a <radical>snake</radical> suddenly appears! Wait, that's not a snake, it's your <kanji>arm</kanji>, sticking out from under the roof.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>arm</kanji> is exposed to the moon and the outside and you feel a chill. Where are your clothes? Ah, you're n<reading>ude, eh</reading> (うで)?! I guess it is pretty common to sleep in the nude, eh?

meaning_mnemonic: You approach the <radical>Moon</radical> in a <radical>helicopter</radical> and see a <radical>woman</radical> there on the surface, touching her <kanji>waist</kanji>. She's posing with one hand on her waist, like she's Sailor Moon or something. I guess that would explain what she's doing here on the Moon!
reading_mnemonic: Once you get close, you see that her <kanji>waist</kanji> looks weird and… puffy? You realize she's stuffed some <reading>子 shee</reading>p (こし) under her skirt's waistband to line her waist with them. Guess it's cold up here on the moon, so the 子 sheep keep her waist warm. And they had to be 子 sheep, otherwise they wouldn't be small enough to fit under her clothes.

meaning_mnemonic: If, at a certain <radical>angle</radical>, you approach an <radical>insect</radical>, you’ll be able to <kanji>touch</kanji> it without it noticing. Most of the time, insects will run away from you when you try and touch them, but if you do so from the right angle, the insect will have no idea.
reading_mnemonic: Uh oh, looks like this particular insect is a lightning bug so when you <kanji>touch</kanji> it you get a <reading>shock</reading> (しょく). Did you know that lightning bugs contain bazillions of volts inside them? Well they do, and if you touch one, you get a shock. A very big shock.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>cross</radical> for a <radical>drunkard</radical>'s <radical>car</radical>, to <kanji>place on</kanji> its dashboard. Drunkards should not drive, and when you <kanji>put on</kanji> a cross, it prevents the car from starting!
reading_mnemonic: You have a lot of crosses to <kanji>place on</kanji> drunkard cars, so you get your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい) to do it for you. The cyborg doesn't need sleep, so it can patrol the streets 24/7 for the sake of public safety. What a saintly cyborg.

meaning_mnemonic: Behind the <radical>flag</radical> lies a <radical>mask</radical>—yet another <kanji>layer</kanji> of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe.
reading_mnemonic: Someone jumps up on stage and starts peeling off your <kanji>layer</kanji>s! You stand there, first goes the flag, then the mask, then ... your <reading>sou</reading>l (そう) is laid bare. No, literally. You don't have a body, your soul was under that mask. And now it's floating there for all to see.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>lantern</radical> on top of a <radical>knife</radical> in the <radical>dirt</radical>. You walk up to take the knife and lantern when you realize it's just a <kanji>model</kanji>. It all looked real from far away, but now that you're up close you can see none of it is real.
reading_mnemonic: You touch the <kanji>model</kanji> and see that it's made of <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい)! Someone really into lanterns and knives must have been given this model cake as a birthday present! Though they left it out here so they probably didn't like it.

meaning_mnemonic: There are people under a <radical>canopy</radical> on the <radical>street</radical> forming their own <kanji>agency</kanji>. They're banding together right here in the street, making a new <kanji>government office</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic:
This new <kanji>agency</kanji> is just starting to make progress when you hear a low rumble... then a screech.

"THIS IS MY STREET. NO NEW AGENCIES ON MY STREET!" Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) cries as she barrels into everyone.

meaning_mnemonic: If you use your <radical>spirit</radical> to <radical>see</radical> something, it means you really <kanji>look at</kanji> it. You're not just seeing something passively with your eyes, you're actually looking at it with your whole spirit.
reading_mnemonic: The first thing you want to <kanji>look at</kanji> like this is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し). You've seen a lot of sheep, but you've never really looked at them closely, so your image of them is kind of… woolly.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>sheep</radical> tries its hoof at <radical>construction</radical>, it gains <kanji>distinction</kanji>. Now that is something that really sets a sheep apart! After all, have you ever seen a sheep working in construction?
reading_mnemonic: The extra <kanji>distinction</kanji> of this sheep is that its really skilled with a <reading>saw</reading> (さ). That's why it's so good at construction.

meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical>. It is pulling the bamboo off, because it wants to use it to make a long <kanji>pipe</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>pipe</kanji> will be for Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん), who would like some pipes for his house.

meaning_mnemonic: When <radical>dawn</radical> reaches this <radical>village</radical> it increases in <kanji>quantity</kanji>. That's right. Every morning the <kanji>amount</kanji> of people or animals living here goes up by at least one.
reading_mnemonic: Today's dawn has brought with it an increase in the <kanji>quantity</kanji> of <reading>row</reading>(りょう) boats! Aww, aren't they cute? Look at all of the new row boats lined up together. They all have their own sets of oars too.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dirt</radical> where you just <radical>stand</radical> and <radical>see</radical> is a <kanji>boundary</kanji>. You don't want to cross the boundary, you just stand there and see over it. As a general rule, you can stand in the dirt and see beyond boundaries, but you don't usually cross them.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>boundary</kanji> you're looking at now is the <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょう) boundary. Kyoto is one of the most famous places in Japan, so you can imagine its boundary is really clear and marked by all kinds of boundary signs that say KYOTO.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> is showing his people how to put a <radical>net</radical> around a weird <radical>zombie</radical> by walking around it in a <kanji>loop</kanji>. It's a weird zombie because it has the ground on top of its head instead of dirt.
reading_mnemonic: The king also explains that this <kanji>loop</kanji> technique was used by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) when he was conquering cities. He'd loop around the entire place with a net and trap them.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>ground</radical> there's a <radical>ceremony</radical> where everyone keeps <radical>stop</radical>ping. This stopping ceremony is being performed by the <kanji>military</kanji>. They'll march one direction, then stop and turn, then march another direction, then stop again.
reading_mnemonic: You look closer at the people in the <kanji>military</kanji> and realize that every time they stop they take a drink of <reading>boo</reading>ze (ぶ)!

meaning_mnemonic: You have to use two <radical>axe</radical>s to open these <radical>shellfish</radical>. That seems like overkill, but it is necessary. These particular shellfish are of very high <kanji>quality</kanji> meaning they won't open so easily.
reading_mnemonic: You finally get all of the shellfish open and you're admiring their <kanji>quality</kanji>, when your <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ) jumps up on the table and gobbles them down. NO! You try to chase after the little dog, but it's too late. They're gone.

meaning_mnemonic: On this <radical>scooter</radical>, there's an <radical>angel</radical> with a <radical>drop</radical> of sweat coming off of it, because it forgot to <kanji>mention</kanji> something to you! It seems like it's something important too, since they're sweating so much.
reading_mnemonic: "I forgot to <kanji>mention</kanji>, you have to study nin<reading>jutsu</reading> (じゅつ)!" the angel yells. But it's too late, there are ninjas jumping out of the bushes around you and taking you hostage.

meaning_mnemonic: When a <radical>leader</radical> wants to work <radical>together</radical>, it means they want what you have to <kanji>offer</kanji>. Congrats! Now you can <kanji>accompany</kanji> them everywhere and offer them hot towels and bottled water, or whatever it is you do…
reading_mnemonic: Once a year, the leader will <kanji>offer</kanji> you a vacation in <reading>きょう</reading>と. It's an all-expenses-paid trip! The catch is that you have to <kanji>accompany</kanji> your leader to きょうと…

meaning_mnemonic: There’s a <radical>flag</radical> under the <radical>blackjack</radical> table that you can <radical>kick</radical> in order to <kanji>expand</kanji> the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes  there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size.
reading_mnemonic: The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will <kanji>expand</kanji>, and that limit is <reading>ten</reading> (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times.

meaning_mnemonic: A sudden aversion to <radical>shellfish</radical> makes you <radical>anti</radical>-shellfish, so you <kanji>sell</kanji> off every shellfish in sight.
reading_mnemonic: You're going to <kanji>sell</kanji> all of our shellfish to <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. He isn't anti-shellfish like you, and he knows how to turn a profit too!

meaning_mnemonic: What might cause a <radical>tree</radical> to <radical>slide</radical> down a <radical>jet</radical> would be if its <kanji>stock</kanji>s and <kanji>share</kanji>s took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares.
reading_mnemonic: Once the tree hits the ground with his <kanji>stock</kanji>s and his <kanji>share</kanji>s, the impact creates a large <reading>KABOO</reading>M (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~!

examples.en: This is very nicely designed building, isn't it?
examples.ja: すてきなデザインの建物ですね。

examples.en: The building will house a number of offices.
examples.ja: この建物には、たくさんのオフィスが入る予定です。

examples.en: See that red building over there? That red building is a local art gallery.
examples.ja: あそこに赤い建物があるのが見えますか？あの赤い建物は、地元のアートギャラリーです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a <kanji>build</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>, or perhaps a <kanji>build</kanji>ing <kanji>thing</kanji>. In other words, a <vocabulary>building</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>structure</vocabulary>. 

建物 is a very general word that can refer to any kind of building, including residential buildings, commercial buildings, or public facilities.
reading_mnemonic: The reading might look a little strange, but makes sense once you get it. You already know that the verb 建てる means "to build", and that a もの is a "thing". Now just remove the る part from the verb to make it a noun, combine it with もの, and we get <reading>たてもの</reading>! Just remember that it’s all kun’yomi since it comes from the verb 建てる.

examples.en: We should review this paper again.
examples.ja: この論文はもう一度審査にかけるべきだ。

examples.en: Takahashi won't be coming to the office next week because he's scheduled to judge a contest.
examples.ja: 高橋は来週はコンテストの審査をすることになっているからオフィスには来ませんよ。

examples.en: The immigration inspector, who stamped my passport with the landing permission seal, looked just like Koichi.
examples.ja: 私のパスポートに上陸許可の判子を押してくれた入国審査官は、コウイチにそっくりでした。

meaning_mnemonic: I will <kanji>judge</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> you. This is an <vocabulary>examination</vocabulary>, so we'll see if you pass.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’m not only a referee, but also a sports analyst.
examples.ja: 私は審判でもあり、スポーツ解説者でもあります。

examples.en: That sports college has established a refereeing course too.
examples.ja: そのスポーツ大学には、審判コースも設けられています。

examples.en: Passing judgment wasn't as easy as I'd expected.
examples.ja: 審判を下すのは思ったよりも簡単な事ではなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: This word has <kanji>judge</kanji> and <kanji>judge</kanji> in it, so it has something to do with <vocabulary>judgment</vocabulary>. It's usually used in sports, so it's the <vocabulary>referee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>umpire</vocabulary>, depending on your sport of choice.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for rendaku turning はん into ぱん (as is so often the case after ん).

examples.en: Oh, does everyone in Japan take their shoes off in the house?
examples.ja: え、日本ではみんな家の中でクツを脱ぐんですか？

examples.en: I usually spend Sundays in my pajamas.
examples.ja: 日曜はたいていパジャマを脱がずに過ごします。

examples.en: "Alright, I'll take my clothes off no matter what the temperature is." "Good! That's the spirit."
examples.ja: 「分かったよ。気温が何度だろうが、服を脱いでやるよ。」「いいぞ。その意気だ。」

examples.en: Jonathan instructed employees to remove their hats while in the office.
examples.ja: ジョナサンは、社員達にオフィスの中では帽子を脱ぐよう指示しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>undress</kanji> and the verb is <vocabulary>to undress</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go <vocabulary>to undress</vocabulary> your goal is to become <reading>nu</reading>de (ぬ).

examples.en: I bought these rain boots at an unbelievably low price, but they aren’t waterproof.
examples.ja: 私はこの長靴を驚くほどの安値で買いましたが、防水加工がされてませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cheap</kanji> <kanji>value</kanji>d item comes at a <vocabulary>low price</vocabulary>. What a good deal!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: I always end up buying stocks when they’re high.
examples.ja: いつも高値の時に株を買ってしまうんです。

examples.en: We sold our property last week, but it didn't get as high a price as we hoped for.
examples.ja: 先週、家を売ったんですが、希望していたほどの高値では売れませんでした。

examples.en: Koichi’s secret diary fetched a record high price at the auction.
examples.ja: コウイチの秘密の日記が、オークションで歴代最高値で落札された。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>value</kanji>. If you paid for something that had a tall value, it would have a <vocabulary>high price</vocabulary>.

This word is often used when something sells for a comparatively high price. Like when a stock is hitting highs, or goods are sold for higher than the average market price, or something can fetch a high price at auction.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: "Those are the rules. Understand?" "I understand."
examples.ja: 「それが規則だ。分かったか？」「分かりました。」

examples.en: Eating bacon by yourself is against the rules!
examples.ja: 一人でベーコンを食べるのは、規則に反してますよ！

examples.en: Tofugu has established strict workplace rules and regulations.
examples.ja: トーフグには、厳しい就業規則が設けられている。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>standard</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji> is just one of the <vocabulary>rule</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>regulation</vocabulary>s. Nothing weird about these rules.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Lead a more disciplined life.
examples.ja: もっと規律正しい生活をしなさい。

examples.en: From now on, I will properly follow the rules.
examples.ja: これからは、ちゃんと規律を守ります。

examples.en: I swear I followed the rules and didn’t drink, not even a drop.
examples.ja: 規律に従って酒は一滴たりとも飲んでいないと断言します。

examples.en: Their discipline is so strict that apparently even some Buddhist monks run away.
examples.ja: 規律が厳しすぎて逃げ出す仏僧もいるらしい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>standard</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is the <vocabulary>rule</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>law</vocabulary> you have to follow. With these standard laws comes <vocabulary>discipline</vocabulary>. If you don't have these it will be chaos!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What's the difference between this new product and that old model?
examples.ja: この新製品とあの型落ちした商品の違いは何ですか？

examples.en: There is a need to understand that we all have differences and that we should accept one another.
examples.ja: 私たちは、みんなに違いがあることを理解し、認め合う必要があります。

examples.en: I don’t understand the difference at all between a janitor and an executive vice president.
examples.ja: 清掃員と副社長の違いなんて全く分からないね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you'd think it's probably an adjective. However in this case, it's a noun. What's the noun form of <kanji>different</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>difference</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Not different at all.

examples.en: Let's try a different approach.
examples.ja: 違うアプローチも試してみましょう。

examples.en: I felt as if I had met the person  before, but apparently I was wrong.
examples.ja: 今の人、どこかで会った気がしたんですが、違ったみたいです。

examples.en: Compared to veteran employees, the base pay of new employees isn’t very high.
examples.ja: ベテラン社員とは違って、新入社員の基本給はあまり高くない。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>different</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be different</vocabulary>... and of course, to be different is also <vocabulary>to be wrong</vocabulary> in Japan. Don't be different!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's not different at all.

examples.en: Today is the day for burnable garbage, isn’t it?
examples.ja: 今日は可燃ゴミの日だよね。

examples.en: Could you not put non-burnable trash in with the burnable trash please?
examples.ja: 可燃ゴミの中に不可燃ゴミを交ぜないでくれませんか？

examples.en: The only thing you’re getting for Christmas from me is burnable garbage.
examples.ja: あなたが私から貰うクリスマスプレゼントは、可燃ごみだけだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Possible</kanji> to <kanji>burn</kanji> ゴミ (garbage). This is <vocabulary>burnable garbage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Our cafe is opening for business as of today.
examples.ja: 私たちのカフェは、今日から営業するんです。

examples.en: This shop should have still been in business last month…
examples.ja: このお店、先月は営業していたはずなんだけど...。

examples.en: Do you know how much money a fortune teller doing business on the street makes?
examples.ja: 道ばたで営業する占い師が、どれくらいのお金を稼ぐのか知ってる？

meaning_mnemonic: The word 営業 is <kanji>business</kanji>. The verb version of that (to do a business) becomes <vocabulary>to run a business</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, it shares the reading with 営業.

examples.en: Japan has a lot of traditional culture.
examples.ja: 日本には伝統的な文化がたくさんあります。

examples.en: This festival is a traditional event, but it now incorporates a modern essence as well.
examples.ja: このお祭りは伝統的な行事ですが、今では現代的なエッセンスも加えられています。

examples.en: Kimono are Japan’s traditional attire, and fundoshi are the traditional Japanese underwear for men.
examples.ja: 着物は日本の伝統的な衣装で、褌は、伝統的な日本の男性用下着です。

meaning_mnemonic: If 伝統 is "tradition," then adding a 的 (<kanji>-al</kanji>) to it would make it <vocabulary>traditional</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why don’t you at least let yourself relax on your birthday?
examples.ja: 誕生日ぐらい、肩の力をぬいたら？

examples.en: I was the only one not invited to WaniKani's birthday party, so I felt left out.
examples.ja: 私だけワニカニの誕生日会に呼んでもらえなくて、無視された気分になった。

examples.en: "Can I bring a friend to your birthday party?" "Of course! The more people we have, the more fun it will be."
examples.ja: 「君の誕生日会に友達を連れて行ってもいい？」「もちろん！ 人数が多ければ多いほど楽しいしね。」

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 誕生 is <kanji>birth</kanji>? If you add <kanji>day</kanji> on there, you have a <vocabulary>birthday</vocabulary>. Happy birthday!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but with this word 日 uses the kun'yomi ひ, which is turned into び due to rendaku.

examples.en: I overslept and wasn't able to properly warm up my shoulders before the match.
examples.ja: 寝坊して、試合前に肩をちゃんと作れなかったんだ。

examples.en: I overslept too often, so the president finally advised me to resign.
examples.ja: 寝坊しすぎて、ついに社長から肩をたたかれた。

examples.en: I thought, "Oh no! I overslept," but thankfully, it was Sunday.
examples.ja: 「しまった！寝坊した！」と思ったんですが、有り難いことに日曜日でした。

meaning_mnemonic: 寝坊 is <kanji>oversleep</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to oversleep</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It also just takes the reading from 寝坊.

examples.en: Please change this i-adjective into the past tense.
examples.ja: この形容詞を過去形に変えてください。

examples.en: Don’t you use the past tense in this case?
examples.ja: この場合は過去形は使わないんですか？

examples.en: Can you explain the difference between the past tense and the past perfect tense in a simple way?
examples.ja: 過去形と過去完了形の違いをやさしく説明してくれますか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>past</kanji> <kanji>shape</kanji> is how things were in the past. To describe those things (like you would with an adjective, aka 形容詞), you'd use <vocabulary>past tense</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My child has too much on his mind and has trouble focusing on one thing.
examples.ja: うちの子は、気が多過ぎて一つのことに集中するのが苦手なんです。

examples.en: I will pick you up shortly after 5 o'clock.
examples.ja: 五時過ぎにむかえに行きます。

examples.en: You get paid way too much for working such short hours.
examples.ja: 短時間の仕事で良い給料をもらい過ぎだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 過ぎる is <vocabulary>to pass</vocabulary>. When you pass what is needed, what are you left with? Just this word: <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>after</vocabulary>, as in "after 5pm", and <vocabulary>past</vocabulary>, as in "past sixty".
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 過ぎる. Know that and you know <vocabulary>too much</vocabulary>. Dial it down to get 過ぎ.

examples.en: What counter measures for earthquakes are you taking at your house?
examples.ja: あなたの家ではどんな地震対策をしていますか。

examples.en: It is said that the Japanese government is taking measures to address the declining birthrate, but aren't all of these measures somewhat inadequate?
examples.ja: 日本政府は少子化対策を進めているって言うけど、どの対策もビミョーなものばかりじゃない？

examples.en: When I tried to make coffee and pressed the button, the coffee maker caught fire. We need to find the cause of this malfunction and take preventive measures to avoid it happening again.
examples.ja: コーヒーを入れようとしてボタンを押したら、コーヒーメーカーが火を噴いたの。不具合の原因を見つけて、再発防止対策を講じなきゃいけないわ。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>plan</kanji> is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your <vocabulary>counter plan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I guess the values of young people are getting updated more and more.
examples.ja: やっぱり、若者たちの価値観はどんどんアップデートされていってるよね。

examples.en: I have no intention of attending a party with people who have different values than my own.
examples.ja: 私は価値観の違う人達のパーティに出席する気はありません。

examples.en: I think it’s quite important to share similar values with your spouse.
examples.ja: 結婚相手と価値観が近いことって結構大切だと思うんだよねー。

meaning_mnemonic: These <kanji>view</kanji>s that have <kanji>merit</kanji> (価値) are your <vocabulary>values</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I was in middle school I was a member of the cheering section for the baseball club.
examples.ja: 中学校の時は野球部の応援団の一員でした。

examples.en: Koichi just shrugged his shoulders when asked about the Tofugu rooting section.
examples.ja: コウイチは、トーフグ応援団について聞かれても、肩をすくめるだけだった。

examples.en: Hey, you're the leader of the cheer squad, right? I’ve heard a lot about you.
examples.ja: ああ、君が応援団長だね？噂はかねがね伺っておるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>group</kanji> that <kanji>roots for</kanji> you is your <vocabulary>rooting section</vocabulary> or <vocabulary> cheer squad</vocabulary>. Go go go you!

応援団 tend to wear black school uniforms and support their team with lively chants and energetic performances. They can also have cheerleaders with pom-poms, but those are usually just called チアリーダー.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 応援 is a word you've seen before, so if you know that this word will be easier.

examples.en: I learned a wrestling form that enables you to pick up your opponent.
examples.ja: レスリングで、相手の選手を担ぐための型を覚えた。

examples.en: That man over there carrying a child on his shoulder is my older brother.
examples.ja: あそこで子供を肩に担いでいるのが私の兄です。

examples.en: If I go to Japan, I’d like to carry a portable shrine in a parade.
examples.ja: 日本に行ったら、お祭りで神輿を担いでみたい。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary>. This has to do with carrying something literal, unlike 担う which is not necessarily literal (you'll learn it later). And in this case, you carry it on your shoulder(s). You can remember that it's literal from the reading mnemonic, which has you carrying literal cats on your shoulders.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You love <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary> things, especially <reading>cats</reading> (かつ). You hoist them up onto your shoulders and carry them all around town.

examples.en: I am in charge of Japanese language education at this company.
examples.ja: 私はこの会社の日本語教育を担当しています。

examples.en: Unfortunately, the person in charge is out of office now.
examples.ja: あいにく今担当者が不在なんです。

examples.en: If that stain won’t come off, I may no longer be in charge of this project.
examples.ja: もしこの染みが抜けなかったら、私はこのプロジェクトの担当から外されてしまうかもしれない。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>carry</kanji> everyone else and you are always <kanji>right</kanji>. With these traits, you are <vocabulary>in charge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't want to burden you any further.
examples.ja: 私、これ以上あなたに負担をかけたくないんです。

examples.en: This task may be burdensome for inexperienced employees.
examples.ja: この仕事は、経験の浅い社員には負担が大きいかもしれません。

examples.en: Lifting 10kg of rice was a burden on his lower back.
examples.ja: 10キロのお米を持ち上げることは、彼の腰の負担となった。

examples.en: I can't understand why you would take on the debts of a man like him.
examples.ja: あんな男の借金を負担してあげるなんて、あなたの気が知れないわ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>lose</kanji>. Because of that, you have to <kanji>carry</kanji> this <vocabulary>burden</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>responsibility</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There’s a half-price sale sticker on the right shoulder of your coat.
examples.ja: コートの右肩のところに、半額のシールが付いてますよ。

examples.en: Wow, it says there's a massive half-price clearance sale!
examples.ja: ワオ、全品半額大出血セールだって！

examples.en: Time to get up! We have to go to Walmart’s half-price sale today.
examples.ja: そろそろ起きる時間よ！ウォールマートの半額セールに行かなきゃいけないんだから。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>half</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> sale is when things are <vocabulary>half price</vocabulary>. Cheap!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The company invested a large amount of money in developing a new product, but it ended in failure.
examples.ja: 会社は多額の投資を行って新しい製品を開発したが、失敗に終わった。

examples.en: I still haven't told my family that I have accumulated a large amount of debt.
examples.ja: 私は多額の借金を負ってしまったことを、まだ家族に言えずにいます。

examples.en: In the end the meeting went smoothly, and we managed to make them promise us a large donation for our scientific research.
examples.ja: 最終的に会議はうまくいって、なんとか我々の科学調査への多額の寄付金を約束してもらうことができたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>many</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> is a <vocabulary>large amount</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>large sum</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can save money if you pay yearly instead of monthly.
examples.ja: 月額よりも年額の方がお得ですよ。

examples.en: When I look at the amount of annual property tax, I am surprised at how expensive it is.
examples.ja: 固定資産税の年額を見ると、その高さにビックリしてしまいます。

examples.en: I think the previous service was good, but we feel we outdid ourselves on this new service. Furthermore, the membership fees are still only eighty dollars a year.
examples.ja: 前回のサービスも良かったとは思いますが、今回の新サービスはもっとよくなったと思うんです。それでいて、会員費は変わらず年額80ドルのままなんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>yearly amount</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How much is that per month?
examples.ja: それって月額いくらですか？

examples.en: This app is only $5 per month.
examples.ja: このアプリは、月額たったの五ドルです。

examples.en: I switched to a new smartphone carrier with a low basic monthly fee.
examples.ja: 月額基本料金が安いスマホのキャリアに変えました。

examples.en: We are starting an advertising campaign to encourage a new Japanese learning experience that costs only five dollars a month.
examples.ja: 月額たったの5ドルでできる新しい日本語学習体験を促進するための広告キャンペーンを打ち始めます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>month</kanji>'s <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>monthly amount</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I went with the flat rate plan.
examples.ja: 定額のプランにしました。

examples.en: WaniKani is available for a fixed monthly amount.
examples.ja: ワニカニは月々定額で利用できますよ。

examples.en: Excuse me, I’d like to open up a fixed deposit savings account.
examples.ja: あの〜、定額貯金の口座を開設したいんですが。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>determine</kanji>d <kanji>amount</kanji> is an amount that is fixed, aka a <vocabulary>fixed amount</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>fixed sum</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>flat rate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Just in case, I'll check how much money is left on my IC card.
examples.ja: 念のため、ICカードのチャージ残額を確認しておくよ。

examples.en: Oh no, the remaining amount is less than 500 yen.
examples.ja: やばっ、残額、五百円もないわ。

examples.en: I will donate all the remaining amount.
examples.ja: 残額は全て寄付します。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>remainder</kanji> <kanji>amount</kanji> is the <vocabulary>remaining amount</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>balance</vocabulary>.

For example, you will see this word used when displaying the balance of a prepaid card or e-money, like an IC card.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have a feeling that the company is not telling the truth about these manufactured goods.
examples.ja: あの会社はこの製品について本当のことを言っていない気がするんです。

examples.en: If this product doesn't sell, what are you planning to do afterwards?
examples.ja: この製品が売れなかったら、その後はどうする気なんだ？

examples.en: About the meeting regarding our new product, would it be possible to postpone it until Tuesday afternoon?
examples.ja: 我が社の新製品に関する会議を火曜日の午後に延期することは可能かな？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Manufacture</kanji>d <kanji>goods</kanji> are <vocabulary>manufactured goods</vocabulary>. What does that end up being? A <vocabulary>product</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We are now working on the production of a prototype.
examples.ja: 私たちは今、プロトタイプの製作に取りかかっています。

examples.en: Before we actually produced this product, we failed so many times and almost lost our drive each time.
examples.ja: この製品を実際に製作するまでに、何度も失敗をして、その度にくじけそうになりました。

examples.en: Murata Manufacturing Co., Ltd. is a Japanese company that manufactures electronic components.
examples.ja: 村田製作所は、電子部品を製造している日本の会社です。

meaning_mnemonic: A place where you <kanji>manufacture</kanji> and <kanji>make</kanji> is a place where <vocabulary>manufacturing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>production</vocabulary> are done. So many things getting made.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This table looks like it’s made of wood, but in reality it's made of plastic.
examples.ja: このテーブルは木製に見えますが、実はプラスチック製です。

examples.en: This wooden music box is a souvenir from Disneyland.
examples.ja: この木製のオルゴールはディズニーランドのお土産なんです。

examples.en: My wooden bat was broken by an inside fastball thrown by that guy.
examples.ja: 俺の木製バットは、あいつの内角速球によって折れてしまったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Tree</kanji> <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d items are <vocabulary>wooden</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>made from wood</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is this shawl made in Japan?
examples.ja: この肩かけは、日本製ですか？

examples.en: Mr. Murata is too obsessed with made-in-Japan stuff.
examples.ja: 村田さんは日本製のものにこだわりすぎている。

examples.en: The sword hilt was made in Japan and is studded with beautiful jewels.
examples.ja: その日本製の刀の柄には、美しい宝石が散りばめられている。

meaning_mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d in <kanji>Japan</kanji> (日本) are <vocabulary>made in Japan</vocabulary>. Good quality stuff, that is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know how to read 日本 already.

examples.en: Please don't discriminate against it just because it is made in China.
examples.ja: 中国製だからってだけで差別するのは止めてください。

examples.en: Perhaps because China has been heavily investing in Africa for a long time, Africa is now full of stuff made in China.
examples.ja: 中国は長い間アフリカにたくさん投資してきたからか、今ではアフリカは中国製のものであふれ返っている。

examples.en: I’m afraid I’m not sure of the exact number of Japanese learning sites on the internet right now that were made in China. I’ll check on it and get back to you later.
examples.ja: インターネット上で、中国製の日本語学習サイトがどれだけあるのかについては、正確な数字は今は分かりません。調べてのちほどお答えします。

meaning_mnemonic: China (中国) <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d items are <vocabulary>made in China</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 中国 already.

examples.en: I had that suit made in America taken in at the shoulders yesterday.
examples.ja: 昨日、あのアメリカ製のスーツの肩をつめてもらいました。

examples.en: That American-made watch is a new model, isn’t it?
examples.ja: そのアメリカ製の時計、新しい型だよね？

examples.en: You’re saying that you can’t eat American-made sushi? Don’t be so picky!
examples.ja: アメリカ製の寿司は食べられないだって？好き嫌いするんじゃないよ！

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>America</kanji> <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d is something that is <vocabulary>made in USA</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>made in America</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We're using delicious homemade bacon.
examples.ja: 美味しい自家製のベーコンを使っています。

examples.en: Would you like to have some homemade soda?
examples.ja: 良かったら、自家製のソーダでも飲みますか？

examples.en: While I was enjoying my home brewed beer in a hotel room last night, the police seem to have conducted a raid on my house.
examples.ja: 私がホテルで自家製ビールを楽しんでいる時に、警察が自宅へ襲撃を決行したようです。

meaning_mnemonic: By my <kanji>self</kanji> at <kanji>home</kanji> I <kanji>manufacture</kanji>d this. It is <vocabulary>homemade</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The products made in our factory are exported throughout Asia.
examples.ja: うちの工場で作られた製品は、アジア全体に輸出されています。

examples.en: Although I don't know much about export matters, you can count on me when it comes to import matters.
examples.ja: 輸出のことについてはよく分かりませんが、輸入のことについては任せてください。

examples.en: When petroleum exports are reduced, it directly or indirectly affect many industries.
examples.ja: 石油の輸出が減少すると、多くの産業が直接的または間接的に影響を受けます。

examples.en: He was terminated during his probation period because he tried to smuggle heroin on a business trip.
examples.ja: 出張の際にヘロウィンを密輸出しようとしたため、彼は試験期間のうちに契約を打ち切られた。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>transport</kanji> things and they <kanji>exit</kanji> from your country, you are <vocabulary>export</vocabulary>ing them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Transfer my blood as much as you want until you are satisfied.
examples.ja: お前の気の済むまで、オレの血を輸血するがいい。

examples.en: My brother finally regained consciousness thanks to the blood transfusion.
examples.ja: 輸血によってやっと兄の意識がもどりました。

examples.en: She was involved in a car accident when she was just about to head off to Tokyo, and now she is getting a blood transfusion in the hospital.
examples.ja: 彼女はちょうど東京に向かおうとしていた矢先に交通事故に巻き込まれ、現在病院で輸血を受けている。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Transport</kanji> of <kanji>blood</kanji>. Only time you do this is during a <vocabulary>blood transfusion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please take out the nonburnable garbage on Tuesday.
examples.ja: 不燃ゴミは火曜日に出してください。

examples.en: It took a load off my mind when I successfully got rid of the nonburnable trash.
examples.ja: 不燃ゴミをちゃんとすてることができて、肩の荷が下りた。

examples.en: Apparently, the responsibility of putting out the unburnable garbage without forgetting on Wednesdays rests very heavily on my husband's shoulders.
examples.ja: どうも、水曜日に不燃ゴミを忘れずに出すという責任が、夫の肩に重くのしかかっているようなのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: These are <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>burn</kanji>able garbages (ごみ). Pay attention to this on signs when you throw things away. You want to put the right things into <vocabulary>nonburnable garbage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: At my age, being celebrated on my birthday is a bit embarrassing.
examples.ja: こんな年だし、誕生日を祝われるのはちょっとはずかしい。

examples.en: I had a dream in which we invited all of our users to the office and held a party to celebrate the success of WaniKani and their passing of the JLPT.
examples.ja: オフィスに全ユーザーを呼んで、ワニカニの成功とJLPTの合格を祝う飲み会を開く夢を見ました。

examples.en: We are going to go eat Chinese cuisine to celebrate grandpa's 60th birthday on Sunday.
examples.ja: 日曜日におじいちゃんの還暦を祝うために、中華を食べに行きます。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>celebrate</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to celebrate</vocabulary>. When you burn this word, you should 祝う!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Everyone's here <vocabulary>to celebrate</vocabulary>, and all you can say is "<reading>Eee, wha</reading>...!?" (いわ). All your friends and family have come to celebrate your birthday, but you had no idea. Still confused and processing the situation, you keep saying, "Eee... what?" The surprise was a complete success!

examples.en: Have you made a plan for the next holiday already?
examples.ja: 今度の祝日の予定、もう立てた？

examples.en: I had nothing to do on the last holiday, so I was doing things like cutting out a paper pattern for a dress.
examples.ja: この間の祝日はヒマだったので、洋服の型を取ったりしていました。

examples.en: My mom always wears the most showy clothes on holidays.
examples.ja: 母は祝日はいつもかなり派手な格好をしている。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>celebrate</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a day you get off to celebrate something awesome. More specifically, this is known as a <vocabulary>national holiday</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>public holiday</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The letter from Tofugu was just delivered.
examples.ja: トーフグからの手紙がちょうど今届きました。

examples.en: The baggage I'd forgotten at the airport arrived yesterday.
examples.ja: 空港に置き忘れた荷物が昨日届いた。

examples.en: That bartender seems to have a thing for one of our staff. Another bouquet arrived at the office today.
examples.ja: あのバーテンダー、うちの職員に気があるみたいでさ、今日もオフィスに花束が届いたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deliver</kanji> so the verb vocab version here is <vocabulary>to be delivered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to arrive</vocabulary>. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "<reading>coo'</reading>" (く), it arrived.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji: とど!

examples.en: Is such a narrow street really passable?
examples.ja: こんな狭い道、本当に通れるかな？

examples.en: My apartment is super small, but please don't be put off by that.
examples.ja: 私のアパート、めっちゃ狭いけど引かないでね。

examples.en: Koichi, put your toys away! If you don’t I’ll put you in the dark, narrow closet.
examples.ja: コウイチ、おもちゃを片付けなさい！さもないと、暗くて狭いクローゼットに閉じ込めるわよ。

examples.en: Recently, as I observe what my father says and does, I feel that he is truly a narrow-minded person. I still wonder why my mother married him.
examples.ja: 最近、父の言動を見ていると、本当に心が狭い人だなぁと感じます。母がどうして父と結婚したのか、未だに謎です。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>narrow</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>narrow</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you're good to go here. It may be a <vocabulary>narrow</vocabulary> way of thinking about this kanji, but it will help you out the most.

examples.en: Viet always walks with a swagger.
examples.ja: ビエトはいつも、肩で風を切って歩いている。

examples.en: My mom slung the bag over her shoulder and headed right out.
examples.ja: 母は肩からカバンをかけて、すぐに出かけました。

examples.en: My shoulders are stiff, so could you rub them a bit?
examples.ja: 肩がこっているんだけど、ちょっと揉んでくれない？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: His ramen making skills are on par with professional ramen chefs.
examples.ja: アイツのラーメン作りの腕は、プロのラーメン職人と肩をならべるほどだ。

examples.en: I’ve got too little arm strength to carry the luggage.
examples.ja: 腕の力がなさすぎて荷物が運べない。

examples.en: "What do you think of Fugu?" "To be honest, he’s not my type. I prefer a guy with muscular arms."
examples.ja: 「フグのこと、どう思う？」「正直に言うと、私の好みじゃないわ。私は筋肉モリモリの腕の男が好きなの。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I don't feel at all inclined to buy a luxury watch.
examples.ja: 私は高級腕時計を買いたいとは全然思いません。

examples.en: This wristwatch is a memento from my father.
examples.ja: これは父の形見の腕時計なんです。

examples.en: Can we talk about my missing wristwatch for a second? I won’t take up too much of your time.
examples.ja: 俺の無くなった腕時計についてちょっと話がしたいんだけど、いいか？あまり時間は取らせないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 時計 is <kanji>watch</kanji>? An <kanji>arm</kanji> is now there too, making this a <vocabulary>wristwatch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the words 腕 (same reading as what you learned with the kanji) as well as the reading for 時計. Just don't forget that rendaku!

examples.en: That batter has a strong waist.
examples.ja: あのバッターは腰が強い。

examples.en: Please put strength in your waist when standing.
examples.ja: 腰に力を入れて立ってください。

examples.en: My waist is in intense pain. I can’t take another step.
examples.ja: 腰に激痛が走ってるんだ。もう一歩も歩けないよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

腰 refers to the <vocabulary>waist</vocabulary> area around the top part of the hip bone — the part that sticks out when you put your hands on your hips. It includes the sides and the back as well, which is why this can also mean <vocabulary>lower back</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Hands off my computer!
examples.ja: 私のパソコンに触るな！

examples.en: When I touch this with my hand, it feels warm.
examples.ja: これを手で触ってみると、温かい感じがします。

examples.en: That man suddenly touched my shoulder.
examples.ja: あの男が、急に私の肩を触ったんです。

examples.en: I love to pet cats, but our cat doesn't like it when strangers touch her.
examples.ja: わたしは猫を触るのが大好きですが、うちの猫は他人に触られるのが大嫌いです。

examples.en: When I'm on the phone, I have a habit of touching my hair.
examples.ja: 私は、電話をしているとき、髪を触る癖があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>touch</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to touch something</vocabulary>.

触る is used when someone does the touching. It's not used to describe objects touching each other.

Note that 触る can be used with either the particle に or を, like 手に触る or 手を触る (to touch a hand). Using に simply marks the location you touch, while using を highlights your action of touching that specific area or object. So the former is intransitive and the latter is transitive, though there's some debate about that.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You only like <vocabulary>to touch</vocabulary> things that are <reading>sour</reading> (さわ). Lemons, limes, grapefruits, you name it. There's something about sour things that just makes you want to touch them.

examples.en: Ants antennae are beautiful, but butterfly antennae are even more beautiful.
examples.ja: アリの触角も美しいが、ちょうちょうの触角の方が一層美しい。

examples.en: The antennae of insects serve not only as touch sensors but also possess olfactory functions.
examples.ja: 虫の触角は触覚だけでなく、臭覚の機能も備えている。

examples.en: I didn’t know snail’s eyes are on the tips of their antennae!
examples.ja: 蝸牛の触角の先端に目があるなんて知りませんでした！

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>angle</kanji> of the <kanji>touch</kanji> is important with an <vocabulary>antenna</vocabulary>. Think about antennae. An ant's antennae wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennae touching your arm to figure out who you are.

Note that 触角 refers to the antennae of insects, crustaceans, and certain other arthropods, rather than to TV or radio antennas.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. しょく goes to しょっ.

examples.en: This scarf feels like silk.
examples.ja: このストールの感触、シルクみたい。

examples.en: The feeling so far is that users like the new updates.
examples.ja: 今のところの感触としては、ユーザーは新しいアップデートに好感を持ってるみたい。

examples.en: I really hate the way fish feel when touched, so I don't think there’s any way we can be good friends, Fugu.
examples.ja: 僕は魚に触った感触が大嫌いだからフグとはどうやってもいい友達になれるとは思えないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>touch</kanji> is your <vocabulary>touch sense</vocabulary> (or simply just <vocabulary>touch</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: If you are looking for that article, it is printed in the May issue.
examples.ja: その記事なら五月号所載ですよ。

examples.en: I believe there was an article published in Tofugu that explained the difference between the "wa" and "ga" particles.
examples.ja: 確か『Tofugu』所載の記事で、助詞の「は」と「が」の違いが解説されていたはずです。

examples.en: Do you know anything about the Japanese first waka published in the Kojiki?
examples.ja: 『古事記』所載の日本最古の和歌について何か知っていますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
When you give information its <kanji>place</kanji>, it's <kanji>put on</kanji> record. That means it has been <vocabulary>recorded</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>published</vocabulary> in a particular publication.

所載 is a formal term that is commonly used immediately after the publication's name to specify where the information is kept.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is a report here saying that Viet is a fainthearted yakuza.
examples.ja: ここには、「ビエトは気の弱いヤクザだ」という記載があります。

examples.en: Please do not record anything here.
examples.ja: ここには何も記載しないでください。

examples.en: I turned in my essay but I forgot to record the date on it.
examples.ja: 小論文を提出したが、日付を記載するのを忘れてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
Please <kanji>write down</kanji> and <kanji>put on</kanji> paper the facts, so we have a <vocabulary>record</vocabulary> of them. 

記載 refers to information that is recorded in some manner, typically in written, printed, or digital form.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Wait, there are eight apples? Will they fit on this tray?
examples.ja: え、リンゴ八個もあるの？このトレイに載るかな？

examples.en: If you're looking for the suitcase, it's still in the trunk of the car.
examples.ja: スーツケースなら、まだ車のトランクに載ってるよ。

examples.en: Our article was recorded in the Nature magazine!
examples.ja: 私たちの記事がネイチャーに載りました！

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's also an intransitive verb, meaning the action happens on its own, you don't do it. The kanji itself means <kanji>place on</kanji>, and this means <vocabulary>to be placed on</vocabulary>.

載る is also often used to refer to something being included in a written document or publication and so can also mean <vocabulary>to be recorded</vocabulary>, as in 新聞に載る (to be recorded in a newspaper) or 教科書に載る (to be recorded in a textbook).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

A reporter asks for your conversation <vocabulary>to be placed on</vocabulary> record, to which you respond "<reading>NO</reading> (の)!" Koichi doesn't want everyone to know that he didn’t notice a cactus had been placed on his seat until…

examples.en: We'll put all the more effort into making WaniKani a better site.
examples.ja: より一層の努力で、ワニカニをより良いサイトにしてみせます。

examples.en: I believe that this kind of thinking is becoming much more important.
examples.ja: こういう考え方がより一層大切になってくると思っています。

examples.en: I feel sorry that his eyesight got even worse after the Lasik surgery.
examples.ja: かわいそうなことに、彼の視力はレーシック手術の後に一層悪化してしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>layer</kanji> more? One whole layer? It must be <vocabulary>much more</vocabulary> important than we thought. Let's pay <vocabulary>all the more</vocabulary> attention, in that case.

This word is often written in kana, but you'll see it in kanji too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち goes to いっ.

examples.en: This fashion is popular among a young demographic.
examples.ja: このファッションは、若者層に人気です。

examples.en: Mille-feuille is a cake made by layering pastry dough several times and sandwiching cream, fruit, or other fillings in between.
examples.ja: ミルフィーユとは、パイ生地を何層にも重ね、間にクリームや果物などをはさんだケーキのことです。

examples.en: Did you know hockey arenas are related to the destruction of the ozone layer?
examples.ja: ホッケーの競技場さえも、オゾン層の破壊に関係しているって、知ってたかい？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a word that's attached to other things indicating the <vocabulary>layer of</vocabulary> something (or just <vocabulary>layer</vocabulary>). It has essentially the same meaning as the kanji it comes from, <kanji>layer</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. It's treated like a jukugo reading because it's normally attached to things.

examples.en: Now we are going to remove the jelly from the silicone mold.
examples.ja: 今から、シリコンの型からゼリーを取り出します。

examples.en: As for cleaning robots, it is better to buy a new model than an old one.
examples.ja: おそうじロボットは、古い型より新型を買った方がいいですよ。

examples.en: Do you know the model number of your computer?
examples.ja: お使いのパソコンの型番って、分かりますか？

examples.en: We are going to make a mold for a WaniKani statue out of plaster.
examples.ja: 石こうでワニカニの像の型を作るつもりです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

What <vocabulary>model</vocabulary> <reading>cata</reading>pult (かた) is this? Is it the trebuchet or the mangonel <vocabulary>type</vocabulary>? Only one model can aim at your ex's window with the right trajectory. Catapult model matters!

examples.en: Why do you call him a typical Japanese person?
examples.ja: どうして彼のことを典型的な日本人だっていうの？

examples.en: Mr. Kawamura is a typical corporate person.
examples.ja: 川村さんは典型的な会社人間です。

examples.en: It felt like a typical Hollywood movie, didn’t it?
examples.ja: 典型的なハリウッド映画って感じだったね。

examples.en: That's a typical mistake that Japanese learners make.
examples.ja: それは日本語学習者が犯す典型的な間違いだね。

meaning_mnemonic: You learned that 的 on the end of a word means “-al” or “-like”. So what is <kanji>rule</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> <kanji>-like</kanji>? It’s a model that follows all the rules. It's the normal model. It’s <vocabulary>typical</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, so this is the original prototype for the WaniKani doll.
examples.ja: へー、これがワニカニ人形の原型なんですか。

examples.en: This product has undergone many improvements since the initial prototype to become the form it is today.
examples.ja: この商品は、最初の原型から多くの改善が加えられて、今の形になったんです。

examples.en: We usually sculpt a model out of clay at first.
examples.ja: 私たちはまず初めに、粘土で彫刻の原型を作るんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>model</kanji> of something isn't usually very good. It's rough. It's a <vocabulary>prototype</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There was a 1995 model Honda Civic parked in front of the Metro Government.
examples.ja: 都庁の前には、１９９５年の型のホンダ・シビックが停まっていた。

examples.en: Ever since my brother moved to a job at the Tokyo Metropolitan Government, he has become even more dedicated to his work.
examples.ja: 兄は、都庁の仕事にうつってから、一層熱心に働くようになった。

examples.en: Have you been to the observation deck of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building?
examples.ja: 東京都庁の展望台に行った事はありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>metropolis</kanji> <kanji>agency</kanji> is the government that controls the metropolitan area. Their office is in the <vocabulary>metropolitan government building</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: A man was swindled out of 400,000 yen at a rip-off bar and was consulting with the Metropolitan Police Department.
examples.ja: 男性はぼったくりバーで40万円をだまし取られ、警視庁に相談していた。

examples.en: When I was talking with my friend who works for Metropolitan Police Department the other day, he told me that Viet is a man to be reckoned with within the world of yakuza.
examples.ja: この間、警視庁で働いている友人と話をしてたら、ビエトは暴力団業界では無視できない男だって言ってたよ。

examples.en: My brother works for the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department Public Security Bureau.
examples.ja: 私の兄は、東京都警視庁公安部に勤めています。

meaning_mnemonic:
They <kanji>warn</kanji> people and they <kanji>look at</kanji> crime, and they even have an <kanji>agency</kanji>. Who is it? It's Tokyo's <vocabulary>metropolitan police department</vocabulary>. 

The 警 here is actually short for 警察 (police). The word 警視 itself used to refer to officials who oversee police operations, but now it's mostly used in the 警視庁 agency name. Basically, this is the big agency that employees and oversees all the Tokyo metropolitan police!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why is the National Police Agency making remarks that seem to take the side of the suspect?
examples.ja: どうして警察庁は犯人の肩を持つような発言をしているんだ？

examples.en: Today, I took a look at the National Police Agency's website and learned about its history.
examples.ja: 今日は、警察庁のウェブサイトを見て、警察庁の歴史について学びました。

examples.en: What’s the difference between the Metropolitan Police Department and the National Police Agency?
examples.ja: 警視庁と警察庁の違いは何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Unlike the 警視庁, who look at things, this is just the <kanji>police officer</kanji> (警察) <kanji>agency</kanji>. Just the general police agency of the whole country, making them part of the <vocabulary>National Police Agency</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Government agencies often disregard minority opinions.

examples.en: Light is shining into the dark room.

examples.en: Can you change the room to one that has bright sunshine?

examples.en: When I looked outside the window, the rain had already stopped and a soft light was shining through.

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>distinction</kanji>, and the verb version here means… a million things. Let's just focus on a few common meanings. Things with distinction tend to stick out from the others. They tend <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary>, you know? And if you imagine shining a beam of light on something, that light tends <vocabulary>to project</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to extend outward</vocabulary>. It sticks out, shines on something, then makes that thing more distinct too. 

That's why you can say 光が差す (light shines), かげが差す (a shadow is cast), 指差す (to point at), or even カサを差す (to open and raise an umbrella). Basically, 差す usually has to do with causing something <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary>, either by shining or projecting outward.
reading_mnemonic: The reading of the kanji is actually the same as the reading for this word, making things easy (both on'yomi and kun'yomi are さ).
